title: STA 9750 Final Project Presentation
section: What makes a neighborhood expensive in NYC?
text:
What makes a neighborhood expensive in NYC?
Location: Proximity to Manhattan often increases prices.
Transportation: Better access to subways, buses, and major roads raises desirability.
Amenities: Access to parks, schools, dining, shopping, and cultural attractions.
Crime: Safer neighborhoods tend to be more expensive.
Status: Historical prestige, architecture, and celebrity residents can elevate prices

title: STA 9750 Final Project Presentation
section: Questions for project
text:
Questions for project

Can we make geographic connections among our data with code? For instance: can we find traffic calmed corridors, and then identify neighboring properties by block and lot number? Can we isolate street regions bounded by cross streets?
What statistical test should we use to test for significance in tax assessment changes?
How do we effectively and efficiently work with large files? (The tax assessment files are ~1GB)
Is there enough media coverage to identify significant traffic calming projects?
How many traffic calmed corridors should we focus on?

Is there enough media coverage to identify significant traffic calming projects?

title: STA 9750 Final Project Presentation
section: Challenging part of project: Geocoding
text:
Challenging part of project: Geocoding
Once we’ve identified areas of interest, how do we go from?
street -> latitude and longitude
latitude and longitude -> block, lot number
identifying a corridor of a street?
correctly identifying a collection of properties?
How do we do this in code?
